data.title: ‎‘Red Rock West’ review by Josh Lewis • Letterboxd
data.meta_description: A pretty fun little western neo-noir thriller/David Lynch reunion tour with Cage as a denim cowboy drifter who finds himself in a for-hire husband-wife murder scheme that’s drawn with such grim atmospherics and farcical crime movie coincides that passages of it sort of play like Blood Simple B-sides. This is a very Screenwriter Brain movie in that it’s quite good at setting up its central location/hook and the mechanical interlocking suspense logic of its various genre pieces (and it’s seen enough movies to know what makes for fun character personality/introductions: JT Walsh and Dennis Hopper are both having a blast,
data.text:
A pretty fun little western neo-noir thriller/David Lynch reunion tour with Cage as a denim cowboy drifter who finds himself in a for-hire husband-wife murder scheme that’s drawn with such grim atmospherics and farcical crime movie coincides that passages of it sort of play like Blood Simple B-sides. This is a very Screenwriter Brain movie in that it’s quite good at setting up its central location/hook and the mechanical interlocking suspense logic of its various genre pieces (and it’s seen enough movies to know what makes for fun character personality/introductions: JT Walsh and Dennis Hopper are both having a blast, even if clearly not particularly directed just let loose lol) but as soon as it gets everything tightly into place and feels primed to explode it strangely loosens up and runs out of steam pretty fast.

The whole affair is just played in a bit too lowkey and "cool" of a register as it inelegantly rams the characters into each other with a bunch of vague, generic plot gestures towards greed and romance for the remaining runtime when it should be complicating the various psychologies or constricting them and leaning into the bleak existentialism/intense melodramatics it tries to conclude on. It's a bit frustrating how few tweaks away it is from being great. Looks quite nice, though. Great Arizona/Montana-as-Wyoming location work and moody moonlit/neon bar sign lighting.
